name: benzoic acid, 5-chloro-2-hydroxy-, methyl ester
Reason: The compound in question is a derivative of benzoic acid with a 5-chloro-2-hydroxy substitution and esterified with methanol. The basic unit, benzoic acid, has a melting point of 122°C. The hydroxyl group generally increases the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds, adding approximately +20°C. Chlorine is a heavy atom and increases intermolecular interactions via van der Waals forces; depending on its position, it can add around +10°C. The methoxy group (ester) contributes to the overall molecular weight and size and can reduce intermolecular hydrogen bonding relative to the acid form, decreasing the melting point by approximately -30°C. Considering these modifications, the estimate is calculated as follows: 122 (benzoic acid) + 20 (hydroxyl) + 10 (chlorine) - 30 (methoxy group) = 122°C.

name: benzoic acid, 5-chloro-2-hydroxy-, methyl ester
Reason: The compound given is a methyl ester derivative of 5-chloro-2-hydroxybenzoic acid. The base structure, benzoic acid, has a melting point of 122°C. The introduction of a hydroxyl group (-OH) would typically raise the melting point due to hydrogen bonding, which may contribute around +20°C to the melting point. The presence of a chlorine atom may slightly raise the melting point owing to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces, so it could add around +5°C. Esterification of the carboxylic acid to a methyl ester usually lowers the melting point since it removes the possibility of intermolecular hydrogen bonding that the acid would form; this could reduce the melting point by about -100°C when compared to the acid itself. Adding these effects together, the predicted melting point would be: 122 + 20 (hydroxyl) + 5 (chlorine) - 100 (methoxy group) = 47°C.
